title: Thermodynamic Analysis of a Cryogenic Rocket Engine
content:
MathJax = { tex: {inlineMath: [['$', '$'], ['\\(', '\\)']]} };   Thermodynamic Analysis of a Liquid Rocket Engine  Have you ever wondered why the showers in Hell are so hot? The answer is because Lucifer is one heck of a plumber. He designed a water heater that became known in bathrooms across the underworld as Satan’s Scalding Moisture Effluenter (SSME). We mortals refer to this device as the Space Shuttle Main Engine. Regardless of whether you operate the SSME from a bathroom in Hades or a launch pad in Florida, its fundamental operating characteristics can be boiled down to the following equation:
$$ 2H_{2} + O_{2} \implies 2H_{2}O $$
Lucifer siphons off liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen from his vast underground reservoirs. These cryogens have temperatures approaching absolute zero and come dangerously close to freezing Satan’s domain over. The SSME routes these liquids through a network of pumps, turbines, combustors, and nozzles to produce highly pressurized water vapor hot enough to melt tungsten.
This website traces the thermodynamic properties of these propellants as they flow through the primary components of the SSME, which in turn reveals a multitude of engine performance characteristics. The overall results of this analysis are presented with the “bottom line up front” in Section 1. The subsequent sections dive into the mathematical background on how these properties were calculated and provide a comparison with SSME performance data published by NASA and academia.
 Detailed Calculations: 
 Equations of state for cryogenic hydrogen and oxygen. Propellant transport properties. $ H_{2}/O_{2} $ combustion modeling Turbomachinery analysis. Combustion chamber and nozzle geometry. Non-isentropic supersonic flow modeling. Regenerative cooling circuit thermal analysis. Combustion chamber heat flux and wall temperature modeling.
